talks.title: Backing data silo attack: Alfresco sharding, SOLR for non-flat objects
talks.targetAudience: Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:
Building a single content platform for few dozens quite loaded applications is a complex task. It becomes even worse, if application developers are not sure about expected load and content structure in the next few years. This talk concentrates on two aspects of this challenge.

* Clustering and sharding - different solutions for different problems. Sharding Alfresco - reasons and implementation. Building federation proxy to aggregate multiple independent Alfresco repositories and provide a single API entry point on top of them. Live technical experience only - issues, solutions, limitations, lessons learned. Live benchmark data included.

* Handling complex search queries on top of sharded installation. A lot of search use cases are not covered with out of the box flat SOLR indexing. Sometimes users need to search complex nested objects, not just files. (It's more or less about indexing associations - 'I'd like to find all cases (node A), created by the company (node B) with name matching this, and containing child documents (nodes C) registered not later than that date' - it's quite hard to match this query having only nodes properties in the index.) We implemented an external SOLR Cloud integrated with sharded Alfresco installation to serve such complex search requests using custom indexing logic based on SOLR nested objects. In this talk we will cover reasons for such custom indexing architecture, and share an experience of its implementation.

Bonuses:
* Short live demo - Share UI on top of sharded Alfresco
* Call for community participation - let's turn this experience into open source project

talks.title: PostgreSQL: what you should know to improve your Alfresco
talks.targetAudience: System Administrators, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:

In this presentation you will see how to design a robust solution for a highly-available database; how to take your backups and do auditing analysis without impacting production performance; how to recover Alfresco's database just before the point of a critical user mistake, instead of back to your nightly snapshot.

If you feel (or someone told you) that PostgreSQL is hard to administrate, we will show you why PostgreSQL is actually DBA-friendly. It has excellent documentation and a great community ready to help. In this presentation you will understand how this forever free database will help you to improve your Alfresco.

talks.title: Externalizing the permission service in a Business Rules Engine
talks.targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers
talks.abstract: Extending the permission service in Alfresco is never an easy task and should be done with extreme cautiousness. In many cases the extension points provided by Alfresco such as rules and dynamic authorities are sufficient. For instance, the need to have permissions that dependent on meta-data. But then if you have hundreds of rules which set permissions at the node-level it will be difficult to maintain all of this. Also, in an enterprise environment Alfresco is probably not the only application developed. You might already have business rules and business data in place. You obviously want to re-use the existing and even centralize it. These are some of the reasons which led us in a direction of externalizing the permission system in a Business Rules Engine. Our instance of Alfresco Community now calls the rules-engine to ask whether or not a person has a permission on a document. Behind the scene this could trigger a complex logic involving business data which might even not be stored in Alfresco.

talks.title: Backing data silo attack: Alfresco sharding, SOLR for non-flat objects
talks.targetAudience: Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:
Building a single content platform for few dozens quite loaded applications is a complex task. It becomes even worse, if application developers are not sure about expected load and content structure in the next few years. This talk concentrates on two aspects of this challenge.

* Clustering and sharding - different solutions for different problems. Sharding Alfresco - reasons and implementation. Building federation proxy to aggregate multiple independent Alfresco repositories and provide a single API entry point on top of them. Live technical experience only - issues, solutions, limitations, lessons learned. Live benchmark data included.

* Handling complex search queries on top of sharded installation. A lot of search use cases are not covered with out of the box flat SOLR indexing. Sometimes users need to search complex nested objects, not just files. (It's more or less about indexing associations - 'I'd like to find all cases (node A), created by the company (node B) with name matching this, and containing child documents (nodes C) registered not later than that date' - it's quite hard to match this query having only nodes properties in the index.) We implemented an external SOLR Cloud integrated with sharded Alfresco installation to serve such complex search requests using custom indexing logic based on SOLR nested objects. In this talk we will cover reasons for such custom indexing architecture, and share an experience of its implementation.

Bonuses:
* Short live demo - Share UI on top of sharded Alfresco
* Call for community participation - let's turn this experience into open source project

talks.targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers

It allows you to:

Run an arbitrarily complex stack locally
Build (immutable) image(s) with the exact same provisioning logic used for local run
Test immutable images locally
Run a stack on any orchestration tool with the same provisioning logic used for local runs

talks.targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:
Organizations often wish to use Alfresco as the back-end repository for a number of diverse business applications. However straightforward this requirement, the technical implementation is often a challenge since these applications all require specific front-end customisations. When deploying multiple customized Share front-end for these business applications, some aspects such as workflows, dashboards, etc. cannot be easily separated.

One option is building your front-end applications from scratch, but that ignores the wealth of functionality that is available in Share out-of-the-box. Moreover some organizations already use Share as a front-end and would like to keep a consistent experience for their users.

In this talk we share our experience on using multiple customized Share instances as business application front-end on the same Alfresco repository. Some potential pitfalls when developing such solutions are:

* The use of specific personal dashboards for each application, which conflicts with the current single dashboard configuration within Alfresco

* The definition of application-specific workflows, which conflicts with Share’s default behavior of showing all defined workflows

* Out-of-the-box dashlets whose queries are not limited to your application scope.

* …

This talk will give an overview of some of the more dangerous pitfalls we encountered, how we solved them and what best practices to keep in mind.

name: Boriss
summary: Co-founder and active member of the Order of the Bee. I've been involved with the Alfresco community and the Alfresco software since 2011. My work at CIRB-CIBG involves the administration of several Alfresco instances, being responsible for their correct operation. Hence, I have to be ready for the coming of the failure. To reduce the stress, I regularly test backups and the recovery process. And this is what I want to share with the attendees.

talks.title: Have you test your backup?
talks.targetAudience: System Administrators, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract: If you are running Alfresco in production, you most probably take backups of your system on a regular basis. But how often do you test your backups? How do you test them? When was the last time you run a recovery test? In this presentation we describe our strategy at CIRB-CIBG with regular and automated recovery tests, so that we identify as quickly as possible if something is going wrong with our backups. We are interested in knowing what is other people's strategy and share ideas and experiences.

talks.title: Welcome to BeeCon / Introductory Session
talks.targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract: Welcome session. Why are we here? What is BeeCon? What will we do next two-three days and why will it be cool?

talks.title: Contributing to Alfresco
talks.targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers
talks.abstract:
The Alfresco product development team recognizes that we need to improve at collaborating with our open source community and accepting contributions. This session continues our conversation on this topic by hosting a panel discussion with various members of the Alfresco product development team and leaders in the open source community.

The session will be moderated by Richard Esplin from Alfresco Product Management, and Boriss Mejias from the Order of the Bee. Topics will include a report from Alfresco Software on changes they have made to make it easier to contribute, the current contribution process, obstacles to contribution, and a discussion on how the contribution process can be further improved.

talks.title: Content Intelligence on Alfresco with AAAR
talks.targetAudience: Business Users, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract: The analytics in Alfresco represent an emerging interest for the users and the integration with the Pentaho Suite was born in the Community Edition since 2012. A.A.A.R. is beyond the 4-th version and has bundled reports, dashboards and free analysis on audit data, repository and workflows. But in most cases, the bundled analytics should be customized to cover the business needs. In this talk is shown how to develop a customized set of analytics with the main goal to create your 'Content Intelligence' solution that includes Alfresco and not only Alfresco.

name: Lutz
summary: Developing on Alfresco since three years, building a broad range of solutions both as projects for customers and as reusable solutions. Java programmer and Python lover :)

talks.title: Gotchas encountered while implementing an asynchronous transformation service for Alfresco
talks.targetAudience: System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers
talks.abstract: Alfresco Community relies on soffice to transform MS Office documents to text, PDF, and PNG. This synchronous implementation tends to hog the soffice process which can bring down a whole Alfresco installation. To reduce the load generated by these transformations a solution called 'ecm4u Alfresco SmartTransformer' was implemented that performs the transformation asynchronously in a separate process. It was surprisingly difficult to make this approach work with Alfresco. This talk briefly describes the implemented solution and especially gives details for the various problems encountered while fitting an asynchronous transformation into Alfresco.

name: Ole
summary:
After five years as an active member of the Alfresco Community I helped co-found The Order Of the Bee and was initially on the board, until I joined Alfresco as Developer Evangelist in April 2015.

I have more than 14 years of experience in the industry ranging from tech support, systems administration, development, project management, team lead and now developer evangelism.

I have been a big contributor to the Alfresco SDK, proud member of The Order Of the Bee, written various tutorials and video tutorials on both Aikau, Alfresco and Alfresco SDK.

talks.title: Alfresco SDK - Past, Present and The Future
talks.targetAudience: Newbies in Alfresco technologies, System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:
The Alfresco SDK have had a rough life, starting out as a community contribution, finally being picked up by Alfresco and treated as part of the product.

With that being said, the Alfresco SDK has not always been easy to work with. Upgrades have been difficult and it can be tricky to understand and get the most out of the setup.

In this session you will hear about where we are today, how we got there and finally how we can learn from history to create a brand new SDK that will empower all Alfresco developers.

talks.title: REST API of the future
talks.targetAudience: Newbies in Alfresco technologies, System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:

But Alfresco will show us about the future of REST API's, where the market is moving and how we are embracing this future at Alfresco.

name: Axel
summary: I started working full-time on Alfresco-related projects in 2010, engaging with wider community in 2012. Apart from the 'all-rounder' type of engagement in customer projects I have focused part of my interest on the complex interactions between core components of Alfresco, i.e. auditing, scripting, as well as matters of extending Alfresco in a sustainable way where it may not have been engineered to be extended in the first place.

talks.title: 2 years of Aikau - how is it faring and what do we want from it?
talks.targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:
After a time of development without a public name, the Aikau framework was introduced to the Alfresco community in Feburary of 2014. Since then there have been two product releases of the Alfresco ECM product and more than 70 incremental releases of the Aikau framework. In addition to new features of the core product, various official and community addons now use the framework to enhance or customize the Share application.
This talk aims to give an external point-of-view on how the Aikau framework helps users tackle their business requirements in developing both basic customisations to existing functionality and complex, custom business applications. It will look at a sub-set of use cases that are supported by or that members of the community have implemented on top of Aikau, and review the advantages and potential short-comings of the framework in that context. Additionally, the talk will try to summarize community concerns and expectations regarding the future of Aikau, and how the community can work together to make those expectations a reality.

name: Heiko
summary: Heiko has more than 15 years experience as a consultant and unorthodox thinker working in business process, ECM and enterprise infrastructure projects. He formed the first Alfresco partner team in Germany in 2006 and is today managing partner of ecm4u GmbH. ecm4u focuses on creating and distributing supported flexible solutions, modules and services to improve document processes in companies with Alfresco and complementary systems. talks.title: An ECM can only be as good as it's model: Business Document Model
talks.targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:
Everyone does it when starting to use Alfresco as a DMS but unfortunately somehow different:
Creating a custom model

This may cause room for disappointments for several reasons (poor support for model changes, hard to combine solutions, time intensive work)
The session will introduce a best practice model for business documents which ecm4u created from the experience of the last 5 years and explains the concepts, pitfaults and how to get use it. The model is publised on github and is meant as a starting point for coworking on a growing, documented, reusable document model for alfresco.
We don't want to waste time with models and forms - let's create and combine solutions! ;-)

talks.title: Increase Security and Scalability: Reverse Proxy is Alfresco's buddy
talks.targetAudience: System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract: In real live it is a very good idea to put Alfresco behind a reverse proxy ( easier adminstration, better control access, speed up the system using several caching strategies) The session compares different concepts and the differences using Apache vs. Nginx and show hints and tricks to get this done.

name: Jeff
summary: Jeff has made many contributions to the Alfresco community since he started working with Alfresco in 2005. Examples range from code, to tutorials and informative blog posts, to code camps, meetups, and conference sessions. In 2008, Jeff wrote the Alfresco Developer Guide, the first developer-focused book on Alfresco and in 2013, Jeff co-authored CMIS and Apache Chemistry in Action. Jeff was the Chief Community Officer at Alfresco until 2014. Jeff is the founder of Metaversant Group, a consulting firm focused on content management and search. He has spent nearly 20 years delivering ECM and search solutions to Fortune 500 and Global 1000 clients. In addition to frequent appearances at Alfresco events, Jeff has spoken at conferences such as JBoss World, KMWorld, ApacheCon, OSCON, JavaONE, and Devoxx.

talks.title: Would the commercial open source software you depend on survive a zombie apocalypse?
talks.targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
talks.abstract:
Earlier this year I wrote a blog post entitled, 'Would the commercial open source software you depend on survive a zombie apocalypse?' [1]. The post asks whether or not a piece of commercial open source software would survive if the commercial company behind it ceased to exist.

Zombies aren't real, of course, but companies fold, get acquired, or lose interest in their community. What is the risk of that happening to Alfresco Software, Inc., and what does it mean to our community?

In this session I will argue that mitigating this risk is the single most important reason for this organization to exist. I hope to convince you of that, and, in so doing, motivate you to contribute and perhaps bring focus to the organization's activities.

[1] http://ecmarchitect.com/archives/2016/01/04/4054
